scenario:
Billionaire asset managers are trading pricey stocks for perceived-to-be safe, income-producing, brand-name businesses. The S&P 500's Shiller price-to-earnings (P/E) Ratio is at a reading of more than 38, historically pricey, and has surpassed 30 only six times during a bull market, resulting in losses of 20% to 89% in the Dow, S&P 500, and/or Nasdaq Composite.

Warren Buffett has been a net seller of stocks, but continues to buy shares of Sirius XM Holdings, a satellite-radio operator with a 4.5% yield, due to its revenue diversity and subscription-based model. The company's shares can be bought at a multiple of 7.6 times forecast earnings per share (EPS) in 2025, a 50% discount to its average forward P/E ratio.

Dan Loeb has purchased 1,575,000 shares of CVS Health, a pharmacy giant with a 4.7% yield, as the company has been transforming into a healthcare services provider through acquisitions, including the $69 billion purchase of Aetna. CVS Health stock is trading at 9 times forecast EPS for 2025, a considerably cheaper valuation than the broader market.

Stanley Druckenmiller has purchased 245,280 shares of Philip Morris International, a tobacco giant with a 4.2% yield, due to its global operations and exceptional pricing power. The company is shifting to smoke-free products, with IQOS and Zyn delivering organic sales growth of 16.8% in the third quarter. Philip Morris International's forward P/E of 18.6 represents a 20% premium to its average forward P/E multiple over the last half-decade.
